cw_t4IIahisBDldAyruadA.text: Shanghai Dumpling aka Xiao Long Bao.  For years I've been seeing people declare that the best Xiao Long Bao is from Din Tai Fung.  Unfortunately, there are no Din Tai Fungs in Hawaii.  Apparently, Din Tai Fung seems to be all over the place in Singapore.  I think I saw at least 4 while out there.  This review is for the one at The Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands.  During our first visit at this mall, the crowd waiting outside of Din Tai Fung was crazy.  I would estimate at least 50 people waiting.  So we passed on eating there are we thought it would be an hour wait at a minimum.  A couple of days later, we're back at the mall and my brother tells us to try it.  Again, there was a huge crowd waiting outside.  We're quoted a 20 minute wait... not too bad.... Unbelievably, I think the wait was closer to 15 minutes!  These guys are totally on it and they are fast.  (While you're waiting they give you a sheet that you can start marking off your order choices.  I'm sure this cuts down on time as a result.) We had the Xiao Long Bao (of course!)  It was excellent.  The juices inside were still liquid and not reabsorbed like all the other dim sum places.  Perfect!To be honest, the rest of the drunken chicken, spinach dumplings, etc. were as expected. Everything came out hot, delicious and freshly made.  Service was excellent.  It was a great lunch and if you go, do not be deterred by the crowds outside.

y2JuO3PJBR0kVV23tHgNiA.text: Honestly, this was my first experience of dumplings and I don't think I've been missing much. Maybe I'm not a dumpling fan or maybe this place just wasn't good. Who knows? What I do know is that a lot of the dishes on our table were dirty so we had to ask the staff to please give us clean ones... And for someone who is pretty much a germaphobe... That, alone, makes me not want to come here again.

PhfmfZnKY4bn6zN9hAcJUQ.text: Was a busy Saturday night and had family down from overseas so we headed to MBS. After waking around for half an hour we decide on Din Tai Fung and we were glad we chose it. Really good food..with the beef brisket being the best of them all! The dim sums especially the prawn ones were mouth watering and chili wantons were another great surprise! Service was good and attentive and thy were pleasant even though we were the last to leave and it was late.

AfCtxcc9IaJQtLQKxXQPtw.text: Excellent Dim Sum. Everything from dumplings, buns and asian delights was great. Restaurant full of asian people was the approval and we were right!

4ZLSgbZ8GTZy4BOSxQ0Lbw.text: This was place was alright. The main dishes are the best! Dumplings and buns were sort of meh. My boyfriend was surprised at how little flavor was in the dumplings, but overall it was a pleasant dining experience. Make sure you check what you want at the menu outside before you order since they take your order immediately.

QjGLRU0Q2JB7RgLCiP1dOg.text: The dumplings were quite good.  Service was a bit non-attentive.  Had to wait a long time to get follow up service.

TqvbxM6E_JhzxnENDplndA.text: Excellent food and very efficient service. A bit too noisy. Try all kind of dumplings.

3XcLuI7ypXs2BwVq_prVCQ.text: Din Tai Fung is coming to Orange County!!!!!!!!!!!!!!   Near Sears where the Rain Forest Cafe used to be -----  I can't wait!!!!!!

eSpU-Kv_DYnNbinwLsCSfw.text: I love all Din Tai Fung no matter where they are... this one is extra great because they have a wine list.  get some dumplings and enjoy great food.  i always take out of town guests and they love it!

GAq3_zt1RTrnM4mmcgvErg.text: we got the regular pork dumplings and they were excellent.  Perhaps one of the best ever.......a bit later.... the truffle pork soup dumplings arrived.   one of the best morsels of food to enter my mouth.  Amazing.

QkqX59l_4GqAPjULWStiDg.text: This place is always recommended by everyone for places to eat in Singapore and with good reason! The soup dumplings here are the best, and they have so many varieties. It's always packed and a little overrated but so delicious, you have to come here at least once if you're ever in town. My favorite was the truffle soup dumplings even though my friends say it's not worth it. To me, it was! YUM!

_Uxsba_HQvaQUVJ5VHxvXg.text: This place totally deserves the great reviews.  Though the ambiance is a mall based dim sum diner, what they are serving up is excellent.  The stars of what I ordered are the crispy duck roll appetizer and the Xiaolongbao (pork dumplings).  The duck appetizer was like eating duck pork belly (if such a thing existed) in a crispy roll skin. Yum.  Also the Xiaolongbao are not to be missed.  Basically a pork ball and broth in a steamed dumpling skin.   You pop it in your mouth and it breaks open into deliciousness. The chili crab buns and the shumai were great too.  Living in San Francisco I have access to pretty good Dim Sum, but this was better than I get in SF at any price, and better than several other recommended places I've had dim sum in SG too.

h2lNyOq0KApn2UxHeqaIZA.text: How to view Din Tai Fung? Sort of the McDonald's and Starbucks. It's not bad at all but it's a safe backup as it's in many cities. Is it the best Xiao long bao? In sg I am not sure. Compared to China it's way below. Well below but I'm still glad it exists. I would say you are paying for a nice clean environment with clean ingredients. Clean=not as tasty. The venue. Casual. Lots of kids and families. The staff. Pretty good. Working hard.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. Skillful in construction

Q3pDq973BHuqiQYJ4SevjQ.text: A good place to slurp down some ramen or to eat dim sum. Beware that it is a fast-food style place, you will wait a few minutes outside and fill in your order form, and then get the food delivered to your table.The dim sum is actually pretty good so I would happily be back. Prices are a tad high for the type of place and service but not excessive. I was kinda divided between 3 and 4 to be honest.

CfchxgpuTt8xlvo_5zeX3Q.text: The Good: Excellent dumplings! Consistent food anywhere you go!The Bad: Long waiting timeThe Pro-tip: Try the Crab Meat and Pork Dumplings!I had the original when i was in Taiwan (wasn't on yelp yet then) and this tastes exactly the same!! The xiao long bao is excellent as always!If its your first time, try the pork steamed dumpling! The noodle soup selection is excellent as well. Downsides are that service is kind of slow and drinks are hella expensive!My personal favorite is the Crab Meat and Pork Dumpling!

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. Storefront

bPhyP-aL_wrhpJqL56d0BA.text: As others, it's always long queue. We waited for about 20 mins on Monday at lunch time. The servers are all very busy. The dessert came first and the main dish arrived at the very end. Anyhow, it was a good experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. Monday lunch, 20 min waiting

ap6OGzFyzI3ye7DMIUm70Q.text: When I was in Taiwan earlier in the week, I was in the industrial area so no Din Tai Fung for me.  Sadface.While staying at the Marina Bay Sands, we didn't want to leave the infinity pool.  Besides venturing out to eat Chilli crab (couldn't find it at the MBS), we didn't step foot outside to see Singapore at all.  This is very unlike us in terms of how we normally travel, but this is where Din Tai Fung comes in.After check-in around 3pm, DTF was just the perfect place we were looking for.  Best of all, no waiting!Compared to the Arcadia, California locations, the menus were pictoral, which was most helpful but we went for the steamed pork dumplings (xiao long bao) anyway.  10 juicy little packages of joy to an order.  (Later in Hong Kong, we discovered that orders there only had 8 there, but they got a Michelin star) yelp.com/biz_photos/din-…We also got an order of the truffle xiao long bao.  yelp.com/biz_photos/din-… These were so good that we already planned to go back to DTF the next day. Unfortunately, it was prime time lunch time, so there was an hour wait, but it was nothing that we weren't trained for back home.  I really don't think you can order wrong at Din Tai Fung.  We got another order of the steamed pork dumplings, tried the golden fried prawn pancakes,  yelp.com/biz_photos/din-… and the fried rice with pork chop.  yelp.com/biz_photos/din-… They were all winners.  The prawn pancakes are like Asian fishcake except it's shrimp, battered with breadcrumbs and fried.  The fried rice and pork chop was basically Taiwanese tonkatsu.They ran out of the steamed chili crab and pork buns.  Sadface.Service is efficient, though I wish they would refill the pot of complimentary premium jasmine tea quicker because I drink like a camel.I love Din Tai Fung.  Especially since we didn't have to leave the MBS at all, and I love that even if we did, there are 14 locations in Singapore alone to choose from.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. menu
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. some fine china collectibles at DTF
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore

wn2gpE0gPOzy9AyYyN8rfg.text: They were closed at 3:30pm, sign clearly says they're open, but gentleman at the entrance says they're closed. Poor signage at best, discrimination at worst. Will not be back

AS59g1j59BWOpVNd3W41Ug.text: Great atmosphere. Great for large groups. We had 12 pax. Although service was a bit slow the food was amazing. Just as you would expect for a chain like this. We order so much food. You can't go wrong with too much food in this place. It was hot and fresh. Wine was decent so is beer unlike some of other restaurants/bars in Singapore. The wait can be long but you can order/tick all the food you want prior to getting a table. I would go back in a flash if I had the chance.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore

eyctMJ9T24-Be7ZUehgk1A.text: Waited a bit due to the queue (a good sign) and was rewarded by an excellent meal.  Dumplings -- Xiaolongbao  -- were excellent!  Soups, noodles, and meats were superb.

nNGREVpGrVuKEAuDWQGkfQ.text: Got here late but the staff was accommodating especially since we got there at closing. We got the Xiao Long Bao and an order of the Dan Dan noodles. Food was out faster than expected, maybe 10 minutes. The Xiao Long Bao was good but I think the praise it has received is way beyond what it's worth. They are good but not life changing. The Dan Dan noodles were a great surprise. Enough spicy flavor to complement the rest of the dish.Pro Tip. Grab the food and go sit outside and enjoy the light show and everything Singapore offers.

dDK0KxaoJROm437M3wqwvA.text: Best dumplings in town that you can get! Just as good as the DTF in Asia!

1dsCvdsu67bqCoPxkujFQg.text: Been to many Din Tai Fung but this is the one with worst service.  It's an  afternoon so not as many people.  Only waited 5 minute to get inside.  However took forever to get the order then waited over half an hour to get the xiao long bao.   Apparently they forgot our order.  The food is still good.

FBCOjz8a9qL_SQgAl1eEIw.text: I think because of the location the wait time here is always going to be an issue. We only had to wait about 15 minutes but during that time we had a order sheet and a menu so we could get a jump start on what we wanted to nosh on. The standard pork XLB and fried rice with egg and prawns are something we order every time. I also recommend the pork wontons in black vinegar with chili paste. Service here was not as good but it was also crazy busy. I would have to flag people down for refills or additions to our order.

RdOeWkuQIjKXtvCGhWpNMw.text: We came here to check the xiaolongbao out and yeah they were good. Actually, most of the food was great, however, the service was incredibly lacking. No tea, water, nothing. We were seated in the corner and had a hell of a time flagging people down to place an order. And once ordered, took upwards of an hour to receive. The people that sat after us ate and left, then the couple across from us ate, and left as well... It marred the entire experience altogether. The dumplings: delicate, and the wrapper was beautiful and tasty. The filling was meant to be savored and rolled over the tongue. Gotta say they didn't disappoint. On the way out avoid the pineapple cakes, they're just "ok" overpriced and a little dry. Instead go to a bakery nearby and get some fresh to try.

_-P7OPwVlS4DOnbv6R7buA.text: This branch is inside Sands, among all the luxurious brands. I feel the price is higher than the other branches. Their xiao long bao is best for its skin, very thin and delicate, but the flavor is not so good, nor the meat inside. i like paradize dynasty more for its flavor but their skins are also thicker. Ding tai fung now also does the truffle flavor like paradise dynasty. i still like their hong you chao shou, but the Taipei HQ is so much better and spicier than this branch. Other side dishes such as veggies are okay but not very special.

lZpwlGtTAM3IFNYgJLTm3w.text: Having been to DTF Stateside, I was interested to see how one in Singapore compared. It did not disappoint.The wait is pretty considerable, but given that it was in the Shoppes at MBS I expected a decent amount of people to be waiting. As with everything else in Singapore, the queue was orderly and the complete opposite of what goes on Stateside.Once seated though, the food was more than well worth the wait (also helps that you can select what you want to eat ahead of time while waiting). We did not go home hungry. Ordering what I typically get in the US (pork xiao long bao & shrimp shumai) was a good starting point to compare - consistently great. What surprised me were some of the menu items I hadn't seen yet (and needed to try). The pork and chili crab dumplings were amazing. But the truffle dumpling was absolutely phenomenal. Not sure if it was just from the amount of food eaten, but this place made me happy. It was like a rush of dopamine/serotonin/endorphins just flooded my system. Amazing, phenomenal comfort food wrapped in little pillow-y pieces of dough.

l6krnLyNyBBfx7y9BTSb-w.text: Walked in here surprisingly with service within 5 minutes. Seated at our table, have been here in taiwan before so was expecting another 5 star experience. What I got was that experience. Service was excellent, ambience was excellent. Best Xiao Long Baos probably right up there in the world. Nice, soft texture yet with soup inside and the pork mixture excellent with the vinegar. Also tried the dan dan noodles, excellent flavour. Overall was an experience which was excellent. Hope the melbourne one gets better

WQws8v1xMIpO5GUDJB_m7A.text: Excellent service - My cup never ran out of tea.Soup dumplings were consistent to the ones I've had in Taiwan DTF.You just can't go wrong with DTF!JONASAPPROVED!

l0zhFwFr7DHAIab9fyJhAg.text: Dumplings until your hearts content. This place is worth the wait, especially if you're in the mood for some Chinese dumpling.The gyoza (sorry, forgot the Chinese name for it - even though the restaurant calls them gyoza as well) is not that good though, so stick to the other goodies and you will enjoy yourself!

5yvgoPQJZes_JNkq8dY6Gg.text: Amazing vegetarian dim sum. Order a 10-piece, slather it in soy sauce and chili oil, and you're all set. Cooked vegetables are also delicious if you're interested in a side dish - especially the cooked pea shoots.The wait time isn't great, but you'll understand why as soon as you try a bite of food. Reasonable prices, delicious, and definitely worth a stop into in Singapore.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore

lk60FCuhB8omxlRRnHkMGQ.text: Knew I had to visit Din Tai Fung because I've already heard so many good things! Did it live up to all my expectations? Yes! We ordered the large crate of Xiao Long Bao, Dan Dan noodles, and the Shrimp Dumpling Noodle Soup. The Xiao Long Bao was our personal favorite. They were amazing! The broth on the inside was so flavorful! We could have probably eaten our entire body weight in Xiao Long Baos! A close second was the dan dan noodles. The sesame flavoring was particularly strong in this version but I didn't mind it! Added some chili oil to make it spicy and it was yummy! The noodle soup was nothing special. Broth was good. The noodles were the exact same ones as the ones in the dan dan noodles. Wasn't blown away but there wasn't anything to really complain about either! Would definitely come back again to try other things on the menu!

c9Bc1wmSOZqJbaKRmkbpdA.text: I don't want to say all Din Tai Fung chains are the same, because they're not. Wait time, service, attention to detail, promptness, and taste all seem to have some slight differences- this specific one is very keen on efficient customer service. This DTF does not have proper AC. It's very stuffy inside. Aside from that, there's nothing really to complain about. The place is managed well- take a number, walk MBS around for 45-60 minutes, come back, and get seated. Maybe a 30 minute wait for your orders to arrive. Like every other worldwide DTF location, you can gawk at the kitchen workers making the dumplings through the window. I still have an appreciation for the level of detail that goes into each individual dumpling, but I do not distinguish these XLB's or dumplings to be better or worse than the other DTF's I've been to. My main local DTF is in Bellevue, WA (USA), and it has one noticeable difference. The kitchen workers speak Spanish to one another, as opposed to Mandarin! !jajaja! (that's Spanish for laughter)But yeah, I'm DTF for some Din Tai Fung.

y-eP98VJwOwMo1Orxyms0A.text: A good friend in Singapore suggested this pace and I now really owe him!! what a great experience. I loved the hustle and bustle of the place, the loud sounds, and the really solid menu. I had a bunch of different things but the Truffle Mushroom dumpling was simply a "religious experience". By far the very best I have had anywhere. I've eaten dumplings in New York, Hong Kong, Chicago, San Francisco and parts in between. This is hands down the best I have ever tasted. Even if all you do is stop in and order a couple of these its worth the trip!! It was a wow experience.

8jnFKOkbEzfr7kmQixO2HA.text: 鼎泰丰 Din Tai Fung A big Thank You to my bestie from high school for taking me here for lunch!!Thanks to her quick thinking too, she got a seat around noon before I arrived. I could see people started coming in here for lunch and there was already a wait outside the restaurant. FOOD 4/5Din Tai Fung 鼎泰丰 is famous for their xiao long bao, it's also my favorite dish to order from here. I could just eat xiao long bao and nothing else. However, we girls ordered the followings:1) Xiao Long Bao 5/5*It's Din Tai Fung's famous signature rendition of the traditional steamed dumplings. The dumplings here consist of juicy meat fillings wrapped in melt-in-your-mouth paper thin skin. Each dumpling is supposed to be made with a minimum of 18 exquisite folds. Personally, xiao long bao the best at Din Tai Fung 鼎泰丰 ;)2) Sliced Duck in Crispy Spring Onion Pastry 3/5*The smoked duck inside the crispy pastry did nothing to me. I actually really dislike this dish among all the dishes we ordered. I do like the crispy spring onion pastry though. 3) Fried Rice with Shrimps & Eggs 5/5*The fried rice was so fragrant with the eggs and it was a simple rice dish yet it was really delicious. The fried rice was not loaded with heavy seasonings so the ingredients really shine through. Shrimps tasted fresh.4) Deep-Fried Specially Marinated Pork Chop 4/5*The boneless pork chop was well marinated and very tender. I like it but it did not blow my socks off. Meaning? I may not order this again in future. I would still recommend this dish though. 5) Mango Pudding 4/5*Again, this mango pudding was very good. It was not the best I had (maybe it had to do with the consistency)but it was the only dessert I would order here. I could see real pieces of mangoes inside, the pudding was sweet and I did not detect anything artificial. *rating out of 5AMBIENCE 4/5There is nothing intimate at any Din Tai Fung 鼎泰丰. It is for families and friends. I have no complaints about the ambience. Lively or noisy. I just concentrate on eating :PSERVICE 4/5The staffs who brought our food were all so nice and polite. Hard to get a staff's attention, my friend needed to order more food. I felt for her. Lol!! I never like to wave or wave frantically to staffs for their attention. Hmmm.. for some reason, i think I like the DTF's location at Orchard better.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. Mango Pudding
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. Menu
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. Wet napkin

coxpY0RZq4Pf-mVuXgmaDw.text: This is a fantastic Dim Sum place in Singapore. What I didnt know is that there are several locations and we ended up visiting two of them during our short stay.This location has an interesting concept where you first visit the hostess to tell her how many people are in your party and are given a ticket with a number. Then before your number is called you need to fill out on the order sheet what you would like to eat. Its a bit difficult your first time here because there are no descriptions for the items and theres only one photo menu that people were fighting over. Once your order is called you turn in your order sheet and are escorted to a table where they tell you how long until your order is ready. For us it was 30 minutes, but it really came in about 20. The orders come out one at a time when they are ready, which was great because as soon as we finished one the next was being presented. The service was very fast and food quality was fantastic. Highly recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore

p8KqswXg3O3C0-vkPRyBGw.text: Except for the xiao long bao, the dim sum dishes at Din Tai Fung are a bit boring for me, and the other dishes not that varied compared to Cantonese restaurants. However, it is extremely reliable in spite of the rapid expansion of the chain. Service at this outlet is better than the average.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore

Lg6GwCFos4C-KgxKClt6Uw.text: Great place for dim sum. Highly recommend. Long lines but quick service. The food is delicious. Everything is made fresh.

qajEu_UZLHOolFA1RvCHAg.text: Easily the worst  DTF I've been to, not to mention the most expensive. Here's the breakdown of the food I got:Pork soup dumplings - Flavorless. What is this mush that I'm eating? Where's the pork flavor? Where's the salt? Taipei and Shanghai branches weren't like this, how did you guys mess up your signature item? Pork with crab dumplings - Slightly less flavorless due to the crab, but still can't call it "good". Pork chop and fried rice - pork chop is under salted, has a weird sour taste? The rice is well executed, about the only good thing during this meal.Tea - decent, but instead of giving it to you in a pot like in Taipei, they give you a cup, and it is VERY hard to holler down a waiter to refill the teaSteamed pork rice siumai - also flavorless. Like wtf are they doing, do these chefs not have tongues anymore? Can't they taste their own food and see that they are severely lacking? Stir fried Dou Miao - A different variety of doumiao compared to the ones in China, but it would have been fine if it tasted good. It did not.Chili crab dumplings - It's basically just ground pork with some chili crab flavoring, hard pass. I would rather eat chili crab flavored instant noodles. Honestly, if they remembered to add salt, the meal would be at least two stars. But nope, one star for you, DTF Marina Bay Sands.

wvINgWiigtriu9dcgID_vg.text: Food was good! Shao long bao is a must-get here- the chain is famous for this dim sum item. Only suggestion is more staff; it was so busy that they could never get around to refilling our water even after we asked. There was an old man there who was so kind, though. he cleaned the tables with the happiest attitude!

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore

6z-4bUOtXeXkIC202RhO9g.text: This location was an excellent and easy meal from our hotel (the Marina Bay Sands). We ordered the pork dumplings, the vegetable dumplings, a pork black truffle dumpling, a yam bao, and a veggie bao. We also ordered a bottle of Fiji water and some hot green tea. Service was fast and friendly. The pork dumplings were SO yummy. The veggie were also good (a good option for a vegetarian). The veggie bao was the same filling as the veggie dumplings, so not interesting and my vegetarian fiancé says the dumplings were better. The pork black truffle dumpling was delicious, but I'm not sure it's SGD$5 each delicious. :-) We totally enjoyed our experience here! We would definitely come back.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. Pork dumplings (top) with broth inside (SO good!!!) and veggie dumplings on the bottom (tasty vegetarian option)

ys17LmZ2QYd1iHLGUyG9VQ.text: Slow service, bland food. Accidentally made our dine- in order a take out (food wasn't even hot when we received it). We told them it was fine and sat down to eat our food. Didn't even serve us water or come by. 鼎泰豐最爛的一家。

vaP-BUbvE0SR3OqU7njTaA.text: Can't say enough how good this place is. A must stop on any visit to Singapore. You can stop here or at one of the others I. Singapore, but they are hand made dim sum and about as good as you will find.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore

dNKlvwDesxCah084MlA3tA.text: Alas, my first experience at Din Tai Fung, where they supposedly serve the best xiao long bao in the world! But unfortunately, my verdict is that they're a little overrated. The dumpling skin was very thin and delicate, yet sturdy, and the pork inside was delicious, juicy, and succulent, but the soup could have been more flavorful. The steamed chili crabs filled buns, another one of DTF's specialty items, were very filling. The crabmeat had a bit of mild heat that didn't linger because the fluffy bun helped soothe the spicy sensation quickly. Despite the restaurant not at full capacity around 11am on a Saturday, the service felt a little slow but were kind nonetheless. My first experience at a DTF was more than satisfactory, and I would dine at the other international branches if I get the chance.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. spicy chili crab filled buns
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. steamed shrimp and pork shao mai
Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. xiao long bao

0cvJVACH6KA7x4Dx_fMlrA.text: This is the worst Din Tai Fung I've been to. In Taiwan and Murica you get excellent service. Here in Singapore you still get the amazing shaolongbaos but with terrible service. The waitress dropped stuff off at one end of the table every time and didn't distribute them better. That said, the food was still great and comparable to the ones in Taipei. It is also about 50% more expensive than Taipei, but that is a given since it's inside of an up-scale mall. You have to try the truffle shaolongbaos. They taste amazing.

photos.caption: Photo of Din Tai Fung - Singapore, Singapore. Place is a bit small. Had to wait an hour.

2Zx83dWRH02HrOtY5iJFcw.text: As someone who frequents din tai fung outlets all over the world, this particular store was extremely disappointing. The service was particularly bad for 8 PM on a Monday. Our order of the standard xiaolongbao arrived more than 45 minutes after all of our other food arrived. In addition to being very late, all of the xiaolongbao were over cooked and the meat had a grainy texture to it. Our empty plates and steamers stayed on the side of our table for the entirety of the meal, and our tea and water were hardly ever refilled. All in all easily the worst experiences I've had at this chain.

3wVeWfZIy2JGYV5RDm2Png.text: It's definitely way better than the average mall food. We felt like it was a real restaurant, not just another place on the food court. The food was good, with lots of options at good prices and the service was fast.

rj19vfUkFBPaKPRyiFCbrQ.text: Love love dumplings here. We try to go to din tai fung in every Asian country they can be found in. They all have something that's special on the menu. In Singapore it's the crab dumplings. They were good just like the pork dumplings. The mother of all dumplings is the black truffle pork dumplings. It's quite a bit more expensive but you will not regret it.

X6wIWgwpGSBe2xbXF3DyEg.text: The food here was great, the only reason I deducted a star is because the staff seemed to have forgotten our vegetable dish, of which we reminded them after our whole meal was finished, and it came about ten minutes afterwards. I recommend the crab and pork soup dumplings and the crispy duck rolls.

zO6DRvXTsv86BSTvVqtIPg.text: My family and I came here at the earlier side of lunch, and did not have to wait long. I highly approved of  their efficient "take a number" system, where they assign you a number and give you a menu to fill out while you wait.While the service initially was a bit slow, we really enjoyed our meal once the food started coming out. We all shared an assortment of steamed dumplings and buns and a bowl of dumpling noodle soup - all of which were awesome! The meal favorites for me were the pork, chicken, and vegetable dumplings. That being said, nothing we ordered was disliked. You can't go wrong at this place!
